description: As citizen panels prepare for crucial public testimony, Daria Tomenko uncovers an active memory-erasure protocol targeting wearables issued to former ghost users. After a tense internal debate, she allows the protocol to proceed, deciding that preventing widespread chaos outweighs the promise of accountability.
During hearings, returning 'ghost users' experience sudden memory blanks and confusion. Key testimonies become fragmented, undermining the panels and shaking public trust in the restoration process.

In a joint investigation, Rada and Oksana trace the memory failures to Specter Protocol—an automated failsafe from the first BCI pilot, created by Halden to erase high-risk memories if system stability was threatened.

As more testimonies are lost, mass protests intensify with citizens fearing systemic abuses will stay hidden. Open calls demand a reckoning with those responsible for the memory erasures and the BCI’s origins.

With trust collapsing, the Council is forced to address the ethical consequences of state-directed memory erasure. Debate shifts from patching the BCI to designing new models of accountability and transparent governance.
